description: From Middle English orbite, orbita, from Latin orbita (“course, track, impression, mark”).

definitionGroups.group: (astronomy) A circular or elliptical path of a celestial object or spacecraft around a star, planet, moon, or Lagrange point, especially a periodic elliptical revolution.

entries.meaning: One complete circuit round an orbited body.
examples: The Moon's orbit around the Earth takes nearly one month to complete.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of moving in an orbit.
(physics) The path of an electron around an atomic nucleus.
(pinball) A path for the ball on the outer edge of the playfield, usually connected so that the ball entering in one end will come out of the other.
A sphere of influence; an area or extent of activity, interest, or control.
examples: In the post WWII era, several eastern European countries came into the orbit of the Soviet Union.
The convenience store was a heavily travelled point in her daily orbit, as she purchased both cigarettes and lottery tickets there.

definitionGroups.group: (anatomy) The bony cavity in the skull of a vertebrate containing the eyeball.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The area around the eye of a bird or other animal.
(mathematics) A collection of points related by the evolution function of a dynamical system.
(geometry, group theory) The subset of elements of a set X to which a given element can be moved by members of a specified group of transformations that act on X.
(informal) A state of increased excitement, activity, or anger.
examples: Dad went into orbit when I told him that I'd crashed the car.

verbs.description: orbit (third-person singular simple present orbits, present participle orbiting, simple past and past participle orbited)

definitionGroups.group: (astronomy) To circle or revolve around another object or position.

entries.meaning: To place an object (e.g. a satellite) into an orbit around a planet.
examples: A rocket was used to orbit the satellite.

entries.meaning: To move around the general vicinity of something.
examples: The harried mother had a cloud of children orbiting her, begging for sweets.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dating) To continue to follow and/or engage with someone via social media after breaking up with them.
